turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And then I saw her.  And all I know is, when I looked in her eyes I saw something... light.  And life and passion and yearning.  And something else I can't even put my finger on, something I'd never seen before--

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: Mania.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Whatever.  And I thought, please God, give me a sign, give me some way to keep this woman from getting into that taxi and disappearing from my life forever.  And He did. She told me the name.  Granted, it wasn't my name, but it was a start.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And if that's not destiny, I don't know what is.

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: That's really romantic.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I mean, realistically, what are the odds that this is a terrific guy?

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: Ten billion to one.

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: That's the guy you've been waiting for all these years?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Aren't you gonna go introduce yourself?

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: Oh, it's you.  It's only Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: KATE
turns.text: Sorry...

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Right now?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: He just got a call from "Mr. Upstairs." Something's gone wrong. He's plenty hot.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'm gonna take her home first.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: I'd get over there, Terry. I'll take the little lady home.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'll come over when I'm ready.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: You know Johnny when he gets mad.

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: And don't be walking off with any of that. You know how the boss feels about individual pilferage.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Talk louder. I can't hear you.

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: If you kept your ears wide open instead of your mouth

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: If I talk too loud it's the fault of the nuns.

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: And what in blazes have the nuns got to do with it?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: When I was a mere spit of a lad on Ferry Street in Dublin the nuns used to say to me, "Nolan, don't be swallowin' ye words like fishballs. When you got something to say  Talk with your mouth wide open," so if I'm loud don't blame me it's the fault of the nuns!

turns.speaker: COUNSEL
turns.text: You mean to sit there and tell me that your local takes in sixty-five thousand, five hundred dollars every year and keeps no financial records?

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: Sure we keep records!

turns.speaker: COUNSEL
turns.text: Well, where are they?

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: We was robbed last night and we can't find no books.

turns.speaker: COUNSEL
turns.text: Doesn't it seem odd to you that five different waterfront locals were broken into last night and the only articles removed were financial records?

turns.speaker: BIG MAC
turns.text: What do you mean, odd? We was robbed like I told you.

turns.speaker: COUNSEL
turns.text: That's all. Next witness!

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: What gives with our boy tonight, Charley? He ain't himself.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: The Joey Doyle thing. You know how he is. Things like that he exaggerates them. Too much Marquis of Queensbury.  It softens 'em up.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Listen kid, I'm a soft tough too. Ask any rummy  on the dock if I'm not good for a fin any time they put the arm on me.  But my old lady raised us ten kids on a stinkin' watchman's pension. When I was sixteen I had to beg for work in the hold. I didn't work my way up out of there for nuthin'.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: When he got up and chased them they thought it was a dead man coming after them.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: I know what's eatin' you, kid. But I got two thousand dues-payin' members in my local that's seventy-two thousand a year legitimate and when each one of 'em puts in a couple of bucks a day to make sure they work steady well, you figure it out. And that's just for openers. We got the fattest piers in the fattest harbor in the world. Everything that moves in and out we take our cut.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Why shouldn't we? If we c'n get it we're entitled to it.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: We ain't robbin' pennies from beggars. We cuttin' ourselves in for five-six million a year just on our half a dozen piers  a drop in the bucket compared to the traffic in the harbor.  But a mighty sweet little drop, eh, Charley?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: It'll do.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: So look, kid, you don't think we c'n afford to be boxed out of a deal like this a deal I sweated and bled for on account of one lousy little cheese-eater, that Doyle bum, who thought he c'd go squealin' to the Crime Commission? Do you?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I make it twentysix twenty-three. You're fifty short, Skins.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Gimme.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: You got a real friend here, kid. Don't forget it.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Why should he forget it?

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Drink up, Charley. We're ahead of you.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I'm not thirsty.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: After what we been hearing about your brother, I thought your throat'd be kind of dry.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: So they're walking along and smiling. That doesn't mean he's going to talk. There's no evidence until he gives public testimony.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Thanks for the legal advice, Charley. That's what we always kept you around for.  Now how do we keep him from giving this testimony? Isn't that the er as you put it main order of business?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: He was always a good kid. You know that.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: This girl and the Father got their hooks in him so deep he doesn't know which end is up anymore.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: I ain't interested in his mental condition. All I want to know is, is he D 'n D or is he a canary?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I wish I knew.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: So do I, Charley. For your sake.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: What do you want me to do, Johnny?

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Very simple. Just bring him to... that place we been using. Mac, you take care of the details. Call Gerry G. in if you think you need him.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Gerry G!! You don't want to do that, Johnny! Sure the boy's outa line, but he's just a confused kid.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Confused kid? First he crosses me in public and gets away with it and then the next joker, and pretty soon I'm just another fellow down here.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Johnny, I can't do that. I can't do that, Johnny.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Then don't.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: But my own kid bro

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: This is for you to figure out. You can have it your way or you can have it his way.  But you can't have it both ways.  Am I right, Sonny?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You said they was only going to talk to him.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: That was the idea.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I thought they'd talk to him. Try to get him to dummy up.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Maybe he gave them an argument.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I figured the worst they'd do is work him over a little.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: He probably gave 'em an argument.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Come on, kid. I'll buy you a drink.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: In a minute.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Working hard?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: It's a living.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: You don't mind working once in a while to justify this lofty position?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I just fnished work. I counted the bags.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: We got a little extra detail for you. The local priest and this Doyle girl are getting up a meeting in the church. We'd like a rundown on it. You know, names and numbers of all the players. You're nominated.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Why me, Charley? I'd feel funny going in there.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Johnny does you favors, kid. You got to do a little one for him once in a while.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: But going in that church, I'd be stooling for you, Charley. You make a pigeon out of me.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Let me explain you something, kid. Stooling is when you rat on your friends, on the guys you're with.  When Johnny needs a favor, don't try to figure it out, just do it. Now go ahead, join the congregation.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: The complete works of Timothy J. Nolan.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Nolan? I knew he had guts but

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Gee, Charley, I'm sure glad you stopped by for me. I needed to talk to you. What's it they say about blood, it's

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Thicker than water.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: River Street? I thought we was going to the Garden.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I've got to cover a bet there on the way over. Anyway, it gives us a chance to talk.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Nothing ever stops you from talking, Charley.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: The grapevine says you picked up a subpoena.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: That's right... .

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Of course, the boys know you too well to mark you down for a cheese-eater.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Mmhmm.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: You know, the boys are getting rather interested in your future.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Mmhmmm.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: They feel you've been sort of left out of things, Terry. They think it's time you had a few little things going for you on the docks.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: A steady job and a few bucks extra, that's all I wanted.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Sure, that's all right when you're a kid, but you'll be pushing thirty pretty soon, slugger. It's time you got some ambition.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I always figured I'd live longer without it.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: There's a slot for a boss loader on the new pier we're opening up.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Boss loader!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Ten cents a hundred pounds on everything that moves in and out. And you don't have to lift a finger. It'll be three-four hundred a week just for openers.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: And for all that dough I don't do nothin'?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Absolutely nothing. You do nothing and you say nothing. You understand, don't you, kid?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah yeah I guess I do but there's a lot more to this whole thing than I thought, Charley.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: You don't mean you're thinking of testifying against

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't know I don't know! I tell you I ain't made up my mind yet. That's what I wanted to talk to you about.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Listen, Terry, these piers we handle through the locals you know what they're worth to us?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I know. I know.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Well, then, you know Cousin Johnny isn't going to jeopardize a setup like that for one rubber-lipped

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Don't say that!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: ex-tanker who's walking on his heels ?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Don't say that!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: What the hell!!!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I could have been better!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: The point is there isn't much time, kid.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I tell you, Charley, I haven't made up my mind!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Make up your mind, kid, I beg you, before we get to four thirty-seven River... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Four thirty-seven that isn't where Gerry G...?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Take the boss loading, kid. For God's sake. I don't want to hurt you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Charley... . Charley... . Wow... .

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I wish I didn't have to do this, Terry.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Wow... .

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: What do you weigh these days, slugger?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: ...eight-seven, eighty-eight. What's it to you?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Gee, when you tipped one seventy-five you were beautiful. You should've been another Billy Conn. That skunk I got to manage you brought you along too fast.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: It wasn't him!  It was you, Charley. You and Johnny. Like the night the two of youse come in the dressing room and says, "Kid, this ain't your night we're going for the price on Wilson." It ain't my night. I'd of taken Wilson apart that night! I was ready remember the early rounds throwing them combinations. So what happens This bum Wilson he gets the title shot outdoors in the ballpark!  and what do I get a couple of bucks and a one-way ticket to Palookaville.  It was you, Charley. You was my brother. You should of looked out for me. Instead of making me take them dives for the short-end money.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I always had a bet down for you. You saw some money.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: See! You don't understand!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: I tried to keep you in good with Johnny.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You don't understand! I could've been a contender. I could've had class and been somebody. Real class. Instead of a bum, let's face it, which is what I am. It was you, Charley.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: It was you, Charley... .

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Okay I'll tell him I couldn't bring you in. Ten to one they won't believe it, but go ahead, blow. Jump out, quick, and keep going... and God help you from here on in.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Time and faith... . My brother's dead and you stand there talking drivel about time and faith.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Why Edie, I

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: How could anyone do this to Joey. The best in the neighborhood... . everybody said it, not only me. Who'd want to harm Joey? Tell me who?  -- who?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: I wish I knew, Edie, But

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Don't turn away! Look at it! You're in this too don't you see, don't you see? You're in this too, Father.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Edie, I do what I can. I'm in the church when you need me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: "In the church when you need me." Was there ever a saint who hid in the Church?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Father Barry.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Hello, Edie.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I'm afraid I spoke out of turn last night.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: You think I'm just a gravy-train rider in a turned-around collar?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: What happened?  What happened?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Tommy, what happened?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry...?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Terry... Terry... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: They're waiting for him to walk in.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: You hear that, Terry?  Terry, did you hear that?  You lost the battle but you have a chance to win the war. All you gotta do is walk.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Oh, I thought you was gonna go to work with all them muscles.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Give it to me my Pop's job

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What makes him so special?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: None of your business.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Things 're lookin' up on the docks, huh, Jackie?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I think we're O.K.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Thanks.  Steel pipes and baseball bats.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: They play pretty rough.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Which side are you with?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'm with Terry.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I'll get home all right now.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I better see you get there.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Everybody loved Joey. From the little kids to the old rummies.  Did you know him very well?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Everybody knew him. He got around.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What did that man mean when he said you were... .?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Aah, he's a bottlebaby, he talks to himself, the joke of the neighborhood.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I better get home.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You know how the Sisters are.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You training to be a nun or something?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's a regular college. It's just run by the nuns. The Sisters of St. Anne.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: And you spend all your time just learning stuff, huh?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I want to be a teacher.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: A teacher! Dong!!!  You know I admire brains. Take my brother Charley. He's very brainy. Very.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It isn't brains. It's how you use them.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah. I get your thought. You know I seen you lots of times before. Parochial school on Pulaski Street? Seven, eight years ago? Your hair come down in

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: In braids? That's right.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Looked like two pieces of rope. And your teeth were

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I know. I thought I'd never get those braces off.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Man, you were a mess!

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I can get home all right from here

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: The thought I'm tryin' to get over is you grew up beauteeful. Remember me?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: The moment I saw you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Some people got faces that stick in your mind.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I remember you were in trouble all the time.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Now you got me! It's a wonder I wasn't punchy by the time I was twelve. The rulers those Sisters used to whack me with!  They thought they could beat an education into meI foxed 'em.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Maybe they just didn't know how to handle you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: How would you've done it?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: With a little more patience and kindness. That's what makes people mean and difficult. Nobody cares enough about them.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Pardon me while I reach for my beads.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What-what? Where you been the last four five years? Outer space?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: When Mother died Pop sent me out to school in the country. He was afraid with no one home I'd get into bad company.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Well he played it smart. Too many good-for-nothin's around here. All they got on their mind's a little beer, a little pool, a little  I better get you home.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Boy, they sure fly nice, don't they?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Do you like pigeons?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: That's my own flock up there, getting their evening workout. I won plenty of races with 'em.  Listen, you want to see them? Come up on the roof with me and I'll show 'em to you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I'd better go in.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I only live up there and across the roof.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Thanks anyway.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Listen, Edie, am I going to see you again?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I really don't know.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I changed my mind. I feel real mean tonight.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Good. So do I.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: The Golden Warriors.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I started them Golden Warriors. I was their first Supreme Commander.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Here they come! The champion flock of the neighborhood.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You don't mind yourself at all, do you.  Joey used to race pigeons.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: He had a few birds.  I got up and fed 'em this morning.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: That was nice of you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I like pigeons. You send a bird five hundred miles away he won't stop for food or water until he's back in his own coop.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I wouldn't have thought you'd be so interested in pigeons.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I go for this stuff. You know this city's full of hawks? There must be twenty thousand of 'em. They perch on top of the big hotels and swoop down on the pigeons in the park.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: The things that go on.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: How do you like that one?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Oh she's a beauty.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: If another fella tries to take that perch away from him, he lets him have it.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Even pigeons aren't peaceful.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: One thing about them though, they're faithful. They get married just like people.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Listen, you like beer?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Want to go out and have one with me?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: In a saloon?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Come on, I know a quiet one, with a special entrance for ladies... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Likewise. And draw two for chasers.  Now you're beginning to live.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I am?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Wham... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: How do you like it?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's quite  nice.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: How about another one?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: No thanks... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Hit me again, Mac.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Were you really a prize fighter?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I went pretty good for a while, didn't I, Al? But I didn't stay in shape and  I had to take a few dives.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: A dive? You mean, into the water?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Naw, in the ring, a dive is-

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Now what are you doing?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Describing you. A square from out there. I mean you're nowhere.  Miss Four Corners.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What made you want to be a fighter?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I had to scrap all my life. Figured I might as well get paid for it. When I was a kid my old man got killednever mind how. Charley and I was put in a placethey called it a Children's Home. Some home! I run away and peddled papers, fought in club smokers and  But what am I runnin' off at the mouth for? What do you care?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Shouldn't we care about everybody?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What a fruitcake you are!

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Isn't everybody part of everybody else?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Gee, thoughts! Alla time thoughts!  You really believe that drool?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Want to hear my philosophy? Do it to him before he does it to you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Our Lord said just the opposite.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'm not lookin' to get crucified. I'm lookin' to stay in one piece.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I never met such a person. Not a spark of romance or sentiment or or human kindness in your whole body.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What do they do for you, except get in your way?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: And when things get in your way or people you just knock them aside get rid of Them is that your idea?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Listen get this straight don't look at me when you say them things. It wasn't my fault what happened to your brother. Fixing Joey wasn't my idea... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Why, Terry, who said it was?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Well, nobody, I guess. But that Father Barry, I didn't like the way he kept lookin' at me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: He was looking at everybody the same way. Asking the same question.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah... .  This Father Barry, what's his racket?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: His racket?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You've been off in daisyland, honey. Everybody's got a racket.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: But a priest...?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You don't believe in anything, do you?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, down here it's every man for himself. It's keepin' alive! It's standin' in with the right people so you can keep a little loose change jinglin' in your pocket.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: And if you don't?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: If you don't  Keep your neck in and your nose clean and You'll never have no trouble down here.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: But that's living like an animal

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Like Joey? Are you afraid to mention his name?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Why keep harpin' on it?  Come on, drink up. You got to get a little fun out of life. What's the matter with you?  I'll play you some music.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I I'd like to, Edie, but  there's nothin' I can do. Edie feels subdued, ashamed at breaking down. She rises, and in a low voice says

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: All right, all right.. I shouldn't 've asked you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You haven't finished your beer.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I don't want it. But why don't you stay and finish your drink.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I got my whole life to drink.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You're not sore at me?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: For not being any help?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What are you crying for?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I thought I felt mean tonight. But I'm not I'm just all mixed up... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I I never knew a girl like you, Edie. I always knew the kind you just grab 'em And I never knew a girl like you, Edie.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's fun dancing with your eyes closed. I'm floating. I'm floating... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, listen, stay out of this mess. Quit tryin' to ask things about Joey. It ain't safe for you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Why worry about me? You're the one who says only look out for yourself.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Okay, get in hot water. But don't come hollerin' to me when you get burned.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Why should I come hollering to you at all?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Because... because...  Listen Edie, don't get sore now but I think we're getting in love with each other.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I can't let myself fall in love with you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: That goes double for me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I won't eat cheese for no cops, that's for sure.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It was Johnny Friendly who killed Joey, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, your old man's right, go back to that school out in daisyland. You're driving yourself nuts you're driving me nuts stop worrying about the truth worry about yourself.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Look out for number one. Always number one.  I should've known you wouldn't tell me. Pop said Johnny Friendly used to own you. I think he still owns you.  No wonder everybody calls you a bum.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Don't say that, Edie, don't...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's true.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'm tryin' to keep you from being hurt What more do you want?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Much more, Terry. Much, much more!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie!

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I I brought this for you, Terry. It was Joey's.  Yours is coming out at the elbows.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't rate it.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Go ahead, wear it.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Pigeons... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: There's a hawk around. They're scared tonight.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie I I never said this to a girl before, I never knew a girl worth trying to say it for, but you you're... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I know... I know... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie... Edie... ..

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, what's wrong?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I've been sittin' in the church.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, it's up to me, it's up to me he says it's up to me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Who says?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: The Father. The Father.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry what's happening to you?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I just told the Father.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Told him what?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What I did to Joey.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What I did to Joey.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Don't tell me don't tell me!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie it's

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I had to, Edie. I had to see you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Lucky Pop isn't home, he'd kill you.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You think I stink, don't you? You think I stink for what I told you?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it. I want you to go.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, listen to me! I want you to believe me. I want to be with you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: How can you be with Charley and Johnny Friendly and still be with me? Either way it's a lie. It's like there were two different people inside of you. You've got to be one or the other.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't want to hurt Charley I don't want to hurt you...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's you who's being hurt. By keeping it inside you, like a poison. Sooner or later it's got to come out.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I know what you want me to do!

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I don't want you to do anything. Let your conscience tell you what to do.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: That  word again! Why do you keep saying conscience, conscience... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I never mentioned the word before. In his agony he grips a glass standing on the night table.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I keep hearing it and I don't know what to do..I don't know what to do... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: My hand.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: It's just a scratch. You won't die. She turns away from him.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Get away from me.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, I need you to love me. Tell me you love me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I didn't say I didn't love you. I said stay away from me.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie, Edie, I...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, I'm frightened. More and more frightened.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'm looking for Charley. I heard Charley was waiting for me.  Charley?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Charley.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I mean it, let's get away from here, first Joey then Nolan, now Charley and any minute... .  ...I'm frightened I'm frightened.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'll take it out of their skulls.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I don't want to see you killed. I want to live with you. Live with you. Any place it's safe to walk the streets without... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I'll take it out of their skulls.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, no, no... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Don't hang on to me. And don't follow me. Don't follow me.  Call the Father. Ask him to take care of Charley for me. My brother. There's something I got to do.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, you're bleeding.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Do what I told you. Take care of Charley.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, for God's sake.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Get out of my way.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: No, I can't let you. I can't, you're

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Edie.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: I thought you might want some hot coffee.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Thanks just the same.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Well, it's over.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: But I feel like My friends won't talk to me.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Are you sure they're your friends?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Jimmy...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: He's going to have to grow up too.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: My pigeons... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry, you better stay in for a while. I'll come and cook your meals. Be sure you keep the door locked.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Every one of 'em... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: You heard what Johnny said. No part of the Waterfront'll be safe for you now. Maybe inland the Middle West somewhere a job on a farm... .

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Farm...

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Then go ahead go ahead! Go down to the shape-up and get yourself killed, you stupid, pigheaded, son of a  What are you trying to prove? With a decisive gesture Terry takes the hook and sticks it through his belt. Then he goes to the wall and lifts Joey's windbreaker from the nail on which it has been hanging. He puts the windbreaker on in a deliberate way, and grins at her as he does so; then he walks to the door with a sense of dignity he has never had before.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You always said I was a bum. Well  not anymore. I'm going down to the dock. Don't worry, I'm not going to shoot anybody. I'm just going to get my rights.  Joey's jacket. It's time I start wearing it.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Am I on my feet...?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Terry...?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: You're all packed.  And here's your bus ticket. You're on your way back to St. Anne's.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Pop, I'm not ready to go back yet.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Edie, for years we pushed quarters into a cookie jar, to keep you up there with the Sisters, and to keep you from things like I just seen out the window. My own daughter arm-in-arm with Terry Malloy. You know who Terry Malloy is?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Who is he, Pop?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Who is he! Edie, you're so softhearted and soft-headed you wouldn't recognize the devil if he had you by the throat. You know who this Terry Malloy is? The kid brother of Charlie the Gent, Johnny Friendly's right hand, a butcher in a camel hair coat.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Are you trying to tell me Terry is too?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: I'm not trying to tell you he's Little Lord Fauntleroy.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: He tries to act tough, but there's a look in his eyes that... .

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: A look in his eyes! Hold your hats, brother, here we go again. You think he's one of those cases you're always draggin' in and feelin' sorry for. Like the litter of kittens you hadthe only one she wants to keep has six toes and it's cockeyed to boot. Look at him. The bum! And the crush you had on that little Abyssinian... .

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: He wasn't Abyssinian, Pop, Assyrian... .

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Six-toed cats. Assyrians. Abyssinians. It's the same difference. Well don't think this Terry Malloy is any six-toed cockeyed Assyrian. He's a bum. Charley and Johnny Friendly owned him when he was a fighter and when they ring the bell he still goes into action.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: He wanted to see me again.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: You think we kept you out in Tarrytown just to have you go walkin' with a corner saloon hoodlum like Terry Malloy? Now get back to Tarrytown, before I put a strap to you.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: And learn about charity and justice and all the other things people would rather talk about than practice? Pop goes up to her and holds out his two arms, his right one closer to Edie; he trembles with emotion.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: See this arm? It's two inches longer 'n the other one. That's years of workin' and sweatin', liftin' and swingin' a hook. And every time I heisted a box or a coffee bag I says to myselfthis is for Edie, so she can be a teacher or somethin' decent. I promised your mother. You better not let her down.

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Pop, don't think I'm not feeling grateful for all you've done to get me an education and shelter me from this.  But now my eyes are open. I see things I know are so wrong how can I go back and keep my mind on things that are only in books and that people aren't living? I'm staying, Pop. And I'm going to keep on trying to find out who's guilty for Joey. I'd walk home with a dozen Terry Malloys if I thought they could help me. I tell you I'm staying, Pop. Pop starts to pull his belt out of his trousers.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: You are like

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Pop!

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Where you goin'?

turns.speaker: EDIE
turns.text: Let me by.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What's the matter? I've got something That's chokin' me. I've gotta get it out.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Someone else c'n take your confession.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: But you're the one I want to tell what you said over Nolan about keepin' silent when you know the score I'm guilty you hear me? I'm guilty... .

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: I don't want to hear it in there.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't get it!

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Tell it to me in there and my lips are sealed. But if I dig it out myself I can use it where it'll do the most good.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: But you've got to listen to me.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: I'll find you a priest.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: It started as a favor for my brother you know they'd ask me things and it's hard to say no a favor Who am I kiddin'? They call it a favor but it's do it or else. And this time the favor turned out to be helping them knock off Joey. I just thought they'd lean on him a little but Last night with Edie I wanted to tell her only it stuck in my throat. I guess I was scared of drivin' her away and I love her, Father. She's the first thing I ever loved.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: About Edie?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Edie. The Commission. Your subpoena. I know you got a subpoena.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: It's like carrying a monkey around on your back.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: A question of who rides who.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: If I spill, my life won't be worth a nickel.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: How much is your soul worth if you don't?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: But it's my own brother they're askin' me to finger and Johnny Friendly. His mother and my mother was first cousins. When I was this high he took me to the ball games... .

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Ball games! Don't break my heart! I wouldn't care if he gave you a life pass to the Polo Grounds. So you got a brother. Well, let me tell you something you got some other brothers and they're all getting the short end while your cousin Johnny gets mustard on his face at the Polo Grounds. If I was you   Listen, I'm not asking you to do anything, Terry. It's your own conscience that's got to do the asking.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Conscience... .  I didn't even know I had one until I met you and Edie... this conscience stuff can drive you nuts.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Is that all you've got to say to me, Father?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: I want to see you, Terry.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You got eyes. I'm right in front of you.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Now don't give me a hard time.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What do you want from me, Father.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Your gun.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Mind your own business, Father.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: This is my business.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Why don't you go and chase yourself?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Give me that gun.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You go to hell.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You go to

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Take your hands off me. What you call me?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: A bum. Look what you're doing. You want to be brave? Firing lead into another man's flesh isn't brave. Any bum who picks up a .45 in a pawn shop can be that brave. You want to hurt Johnny Friendly? You want to fix him for what he did to Charley and a dozen men who were better than Charley? Don't fight him like a hoodlum down here in the jungle. That's just what he wants. He'll hit you in the head and plead self-defense. Fight him tomorrow in the courtroom with the truth as you know it  Truth is the gun Drop that thing and tell the truth a more dangerous weapon than this little   cap pistol.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: ...walk?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Johnny Friendly is layin' odds that you won't get up.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: You can!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I can? Okay.  Okay...

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Who asked him here?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Have a seat. I'm trying to find out just what happened to Joey Doyle. Maybe you can help.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Now listen, if you know who the pistols are, if you see them on the dock every day, are you going to keep still until they cut you down one by one?  Are you? Are you? How about you, Nolan?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Father, one thing you got to understand. On the dock we've always been D 'n D.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: D 'n D?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Deef 'n dumb. Somethin' c'n happen right in front of our noses and we don't see nothin'. You know what I mean. No matter how much we hate the torpedoes we don't rat.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: You all right, Nolan?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Yeah, considerin' they was usin' my head for a baseball!

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: Nice fellows.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Those blood suckers. How I'd love to fix those babies but

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: But you still hold out for silence?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: You still call it ratting?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Are you on the level, Father?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: If I stick my neck out, and they chopped it off, would that be the end of it? Or are you ready to go all the way?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: I'll go down the line, Kayo, believe me.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Baseball bats that's just for openers. They'll put the muscle on you, turned-around collar or no turned-around collar.

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: And I still say you stand up and I'll stand up with you.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Down to the wire?

turns.speaker: FATHER BARRY
turns.text: So help me God!

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Well, I had my fun, I've drunk my fill and I tickled some good-lookin' fillies I'm on borried time.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: You're Terry Malloy, aren't you?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: I thought I recognized you. Saw you fight in St. Nick's a couple of years ago.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: O.K. O.K. Without the bird seed. What do you want?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Our identification.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Waterfront Crime Commission ?  What's that?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: We're getting ready to hold public hearings on waterfront crime and underworld infiltration of longshore unions.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I don't know nothing.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Never will be much too soon.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Take it easy.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: You're being served with a subpoena, Mr. Malloy.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Be at the State House, Courtroom Nine, at ten o'clock tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I told you I don't know nothin' and I ain't saying nothin'.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: You can bring a lawyer if you wish. And you're privileged under the Constitution to protect yourself against questions that might implicate you in any crimes.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You know what you're askin'? You're askin'

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You looking for me?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Not exactly. Just thought I'd sit down and rest my dogs a minute.  You know the next investigation we get into I hope it's got buildings with elevators in them. This one has been nothing but climbing stairs. And when we hit the top ßoor the folks are usually out.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I guess it's pretty tough work at that.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Well, it'll be worth it if we can tell the waterfront story the way the people have a right to hear it. Don't you think?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Didn't I see you fight in the Garden one night three or four years ago? With a fellow called Wilson?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Wilson yeah  yeah I fought Wilson.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: I thought you were going to take him that night but...

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: You want to know something I would have taken Wilson

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: I think you could have.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: If I licked him I would have had the title shot instead of him boy, I was ready that night.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: You sure looked it. Something go wrong?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah. Johnny Friendly and my brother had other ideas.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Such as what?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Listen, this ain't for publication.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: I'm just resting my feet.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Remember the first round how I had him against the ropes, and

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: I'll never forget it. I thought it was all over.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah. My own blood and they sell me out for a lousy bet I had it in me to hit the top and  Boy, if I wanted to, the things I could tell you about them guys

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Well, I better get going. Hit those stairs again.  Was that a looping right or an uppercut the first time you caught him?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Looping right! I never swung wild. I was strictly a short puncher hooks over 'n under   whop-whop!

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah, really!

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Where you going? I'll walk along with you.

turns.speaker: GLOVER
turns.text: Sure... .

turns.speaker: J.P.
turns.text: Condolences. How you fixed for cabbage this mornin'?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Oh me and my chum are just rolling in the stuff. We only work down here for a hobby, J.P.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Some chance at ten percent a week! And if he don't borrow, he don't work.

turns.speaker: J.P.
turns.text: You'll work.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: I ought to belt you one, J.P.

turns.speaker: J.P.
turns.text: Raise a hand to me and... .

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: ... .and you'll tell Johnny Friendly.

turns.speaker: J.P.
turns.text: You'd be off the pier for good.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You're doin' lovely, Terry, very lovely.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: O.K., O.K., That's enough.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: What's the matter wit' you, success gone to ya head?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: I told you lay off.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: My ain't we touchy this morning?
